text: what happens when you fall into a black
hole well of course we don't know for
sure but in classical general relativity
the idea is that as you fall towards a
black hole you begin to experience
strong tidal effects so for example if
I'm falling feet first my feet get
pulled towards the black hole more
powerfully than my head now this depends
on the size of the black hole and in
this case small black holes are much
more deadly than big black holes as a
small black hole has a very extreme
tidal field gravitational tidal field so
in that case a small black hole is
likely to spaghettify you it will
stretch you out into your component
atoms and you'll rain down into the
black holes a single thread of material
that's all you've ended up at but a
giant black hole is actually a more
gentle beast in terms of its tides so
you could actually cross through the
event horizon of a giant black hole not
really feel anything
which is pretty strange because you're
never coming back again
